skills.name: Know that the probabilities of exhaustive events must sum to 1
Assign probabilities to single events using fractions

explanations.A: I think you may have assumed that you cannot roll a 4. A fair standard dice includes the numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. Each appear once. Out of this list, what would the probability be of rolling a 4?
explanations.B: The probability of rolling a 4 would be 1/6. The number line is split into 6 parts so we would mark the event one part along, at B
explanations.C: I think you may have found the probability of rolling an even number rather than 4. A fair standard dice includes the numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. Each appear once. Out of this list, what would the probability be of rolling a 4?
explanations.D: I think you have just chosen the 4th dash on the number line. A fair standard dice includes the numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. Each appear once. Out of this list, what would the probability be of rolling a 4?

explanations.A: I think you may have assumed that you cannot roll a 5. A fair standard dice includes the numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. Each appear once. Out of this list, what would the probability be of rolling a 5?
explanations.B: The probability of rolling a 5 would be 1/6. The number line is split into 6 parts so we would mark the event one part along, at B
explanations.C: I think you may have found the probability of rolling an odd number rather than 5. A fair standard dice includes the numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. Each appear once. Out of this list, what would the probability be of rolling a 5?
explanations.D: I think you have just chosen the 5th dash on the number line. A fair standard dice includes the numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. Each appear once. Out of this list, what would the probability be of rolling a 5?

explanations.A: I think you may have counted the dashes incorrectly. A fair standard dice includes the numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. Each appear once. Out of this list, what would the probability be of rolling greater than a 4?
explanations.B: The outcomes greater than 4 are 5 and 6. The probability of rolling a 5 or 6 is 2/6. The number line is split into 6 parts, so we would choose the second dash, marked with the letter B.
explanations.C: I think you have chosen the answer for a number greater than OR equal to 4. The question asks for the probability of rolling a number greater than 4.
explanations.D: I think you have found the probability of rolling 4 or less. The question asks for the probability of rolling a number greater than 4 – so 5 or 6.

explanations.A: I think you may have counted the dashes incorrectly. A fair standard dice includes the numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. Each appear once. Out of this list, what would the probability be of rolling a number less than 3?
explanations.B: The outcomes less than 3 are 1 and 2. The probability of rolling a 1 or 2 is 2/6. The number line is split into 6 parts, so we would choose the second dash, marked with the letter B.
explanations.C: I think you have chosen the answer for a number less than OR equal to 3. The question asks for the probability of rolling a number less than 3.
explanations.D: I think you have found the probability of rolling 3 or more. The question asks for the probability of rolling a number less than 3 – so 1 or 2.

explanations.A: I think you have marked the second dash because there are two counters. Reconsider how many counters are red out of the total, and what probability that would be.
explanations.B: The probability of picking a red is 2 out of 5. 2/5=4/10. The number line is split into 10 parts so we would mark the event on the fourth dash which is labelled B.
explanations.C: I think you have assumed that there are an equal number of red and blue counters. Reconsider how many counters are red out of the total, and what probability that would be.
explanations.D: I think you have calculated the probability of picking a blue counter. Reconsider how many counters are red out of the total, and what probability that would be.

explanations.A: I think you have marked the third dash because there are three blue counters. Reconsider how many counters are blue out of the total, and what probability that would be.
explanations.B: I think you have found the probability of choosing a red counter, whereas the question asks for the probability of choosing a blue. Reconsider how many counters are blue out of the total, and what probability that would be.
explanations.C: I think you have assumed that there are an equal number of red and blue counters. Reconsider how many counters are blue out of the total, and what probability that would be.
explanations.D: The probability of picking a blue is 3 out of 5. 3/5=6/10. The number line is split into 10 parts so we would mark the event on the sixth dash which is labelled D.

explanations.A: I think you have assumed it would be on the 3rd dash as there are 3 red counters in Tom’s bag. The marked probability is ½ or 3/6, which bag shows this, if any?
explanations.B: The marked probability is ½ or 3/6. Tom’s bag contains 2/5 red counters whereas Katie’s contains 3/6. Therefore, Katie is correct.
explanations.C: I think you have presumed that having 3 reds in the bag would mean the probability was on the third dash on the number line. The marked probability is ½ or 3/6, which bag shows this, if any?
explanations.D: At least one of them is correct. The marked probability is ½ or 3/6, which bag shows this?

explanations.A: I think you have correctly realised that the probability of picking a red in Tom’s bag is 2/3 which is equal to 4/6. Is his the only bag that shows this?
explanations.B: I think you have correctly realised that the probability of picking a red in Katie’s bag is 4/6. Is hers the only bag that shows this?
explanations.C: The marked probability is 4/6 or 2/3. Tom’s bag contains 2/3 red counters ad Katie’s contains 4/6. Therefore, both are correct.
explanations.D: At least one of them is correct. The marked probability is 4/6 or 2/3 - which bag shows this?

explanations.A: I think you have assumed that you would have to put them in order on the number line (win, draw, lose), which is not the case. As they are the only three possible outcomes, their probabilities must sum to 1. If P(draw) is greater than ½ and P(win) is less than ½, what would P(lose) need to be to make the probabilities sum to 1?
explanations.B: The outcomes are draw, win or lose. The probabilities must sum to 1. For the probabilities to sum to 1, the probability of a lose must be less than ½.
explanations.C: I think you have assumed that there are only two outcomes – win or lose. There are three outcomes in this case – win, lose and draw. The probabilities of win and draw are shown on the number line. If P(draw) is greater than ½ and P(win) is less than ½, what would P(lose) need to be to make the probabilities sum to 1?
explanations.D: There are three outcomes in this case – win, lose and draw. The probabilities of win and draw are shown on the number line. If P(draw) is greater than ½ and P(win) is less than ½, what would P(lose) need to be to make the probabilities sum to 1?

explanations.A: The outcomes are draw, win or lose. The probabilities of the three outcomes must sum to 1. The probability of a draw or a win are both less than ¼, so the probability of losing must be greater than ½.
explanations.B: I think you have assumed that you would have to put them close together on the number line, which is not the case. As they are the only three possible outcomes, their probabilities must sum to 1. If P(draw) is less then ¼ and P(win) is less than ¼, what would P(lose) need to be to make the probabilities sum to 1?
explanations.C: I think you have assumed that there are only two outcomes – win or lose. There are three outcomes in this case – win, lose and draw. The probabilities of win and draw are shown on the number line. If P(draw) is less then ¼ and P(win) is less than ¼, what would P(lose) need to be to make the probabilities sum to 1?
explanations.D: There are three outcomes in this case – win, lose and draw. The probabilities of win and draw are shown on the number line. If P(draw) is less then ¼ and P(win) is less than ¼, what would P(lose) need to be to make the probabilities sum to 1?
